p: Drought may encourage the growth of various fungi associated with health impacts. Warmer, drier summers may have contributed to the establishment of Cryptococcus gattii in Canada [ 142]. Low moisture has been associated with C. gattii soil colonization [ 143]. The fungus was first detected on Vancouver Island in 1999, with more than 100 human cases identified [ 142]. Between 1999 and 2007, there were 218 reported cases of C. gattii in British Columbia, the region with the largest C. gattii infected population in Canada and the world [ 144].
